justification: The Numeracy block contained the Berlin Numeracy Test (Cokely et al., 2012), which was used as one of the objective numeracy measures.
Participants completed the numeracy scale developed by Lipkus et al. (2001) as part of the objective numeracy assessment.
The study notes that the Abbreviated Numeracy Scale (Weller et al., 2012/2013) was administered to measure objective numeracy.
Subjective numeracy was measured with the Subjective Numeracy Scale, described as self-report questions such as 'How good are you at working with percentages?' (Fagerlin et al., 2007).
Approximate numeracy was assessed with the symbolic-number mapping task in which participants place numbers on a number line anchored at 0 and 1000.

measured_by: 'Applying decision rules' subscale of Adult Decision Making Competence (A-DMC)
justification: For S01, the study states that people with higher numeracy apply decision rules more correctly as measured by the 'applying decision rules' subscale of A-DMC.

measured_by: 'Resistance to sunk cost' subscale of Adult Decision Making Competence (A-DMC)
justification: S02 describes resistance to sunk cost being assessed with ten items comprising the 'resistance to sunk cost' subscale of A-DMC.

measured_by: 'Consistency in risk perception' subscale of Adult Decision Making Competence (A-DMC)
justification: S04 notes that consistency in risk perception was measured by the percentage of consistent judgments on the 'consistency in risk perception' subscale of A-DMC.
S05 explains that superior decision making under risk was indexed by the number of EV-maximizing choices in a set of ten monetary lotteries.
S06 details that medical risk comprehension was quantified as the number of correct answers on 12 items covering absolute, relative, and lifetime risk information (Rolison et al., 2020).
S03 states that financial knowledge was measured with 20 true-false and multiple-choice items whose correct responses were summed to create a score.
S07 reports that financial well-being was assessed with ten questions such as 'I can enjoy life because of the way I'm managing my money,' summed to yield a well-being score.
S08 describes the framing effect being tested by asking participants to rate students’ work when scores were presented as percent correct vs. percent incorrect.

measured_by: Jellybeans task (bowl A vs. bowl B choice)
justification: S11 used the jellybeans task in which choices between two bowls with different colored-bean probabilities indexed preference for a suboptimal option.

topic_or_construct: Evaluation of loss vs. no-loss bet
justification: S09 assessed attractiveness ratings of a simple gamble in loss vs. no-loss conditions using the loss-bet lottery task.
